VLIB Function Reference

Image Pyramid

Introduction and Use Cases

Image pyramid is a data structure consisting of the original image at level 0, 2x2 sub-sampled image at Level 1, further 2x2 sub-sampled image at Level 2, and further 2x2 sub-sampled image at Level 3. It is commonly used in detection and tracking applications to reduce the amount of processing [1].

Specification

Function

Calculates Levels 1, 2, and 3 of an image pyramid for an 8-bit/16-bit input image. The antialiasing filter used at each step is a 2x2 averaging.

Variants

This functionality is available in two variants: 8-bit and 16-bit

Inputs


    Parameter          Description                      8-bit            16-bit
    -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
    *pIn               8-bit input image               (UQ8.0)          (UQ16.0)
     inCols            Width of input image            (UQ16.0)         (UQ16.0)
     inRows            Height of input image           (UQ16.0)         (UQ16.0)
    *pOut              Output image                    (UQ8.0)          (UQ16.0)

Outputs

    Returns VLIB Error Status

Method

inCols must be a multiple of 8, while pIn and pOut must be 64-bit aligned.
  • pIn is a pointer to an (inCols x inRows) array of unsigned data (8bit or 16bit).
  • pOut is a pointer to an (inCols x inRows) x 21 / 64 array of unsigned data (8bit or 16bit).
  • Level 1 image is of size (inCols / 2) x (inRows / 2)
  • Level 2 image is of size (inCols / 4) x (inRows / 4)
  • Level 3 image is of size (inCols / 8) x (inRows / 8)
  • The output contains level 1 image first, followed by level 2 image and finally level 3 image.
  • Range of level 1 image in output: pOut[0] through pOut[(inRows x inCols) / 4 - 1]
  • Range of level 2 image in output: pOut[(inRows x inCols) / 4] through pOut[(inRows x inCols) x 5 / 16 - 1]
  • Range of level 3 image in output: pOut[(inRows x inCols) x 5 / 16] through pOut[(inRows x inCols) x 21 / 64 - 1]

APIS

  • VLIB_imagePyramid16
